title: Nineteenth century letters,
author: Rees, Byron Johnson
snippet: Is it pouring with rain at Park Lodge, and the most dismal, wretched, .cat and dog day ever seen? O! it's gloomy at 13 Young Street! I have been labouring all day drawing that is, and doing my plates, till my &s

title: Spare hours...
author: Brown, John
snippet: " 13 Young Street, Kensington Square, May 11, 1848. " My dear Sir, — The arms and the man arrived in safety yesterday, and I am glad to know the names of two of the eighty Edinburgh friends who have taken such a kind method of showing their good-will towards me.

title: The charm of Edinburgh :
author: Hyatt, Alfred Henry.
snippet: ' White as a frosted plum-cake, by jingo !' said he, when he got to the street. Maida gambolled and whisked among the snow, and his master strode across to Young Street, and through it to i, North Charlotte Street, to the house of his dear friend, Mrs. William Keith of Corstorphine Hill, a niece of Mrs. Keith of Ravelston. . . .

title: Spare hours...
author: Brown, John

Maida gambolled and whisked among the snow, and his master strode across to Young Street, and through it to 1 North Charlotte Street, to the house of his dear friend, Mrs. William Keith, of Corstorphine Hill, niece of Mrs. Keith, of Ravelston, of whom he said at her death, eight years after, " Much tradition, and that of the

title: Yesterdays with authors.
author: Fields, James Thomas
snippet: I once made a pilgrimage with Thackeray (at my request, of course, the visits were planned) to the various houses wdiere his books had been written ; and I remember wdien we came to Young Street, Kensington, he said, with mock gravity, " Down on your knees, you rogue, for here ' Vanity Pair ' was penned ! And I will go doAvn with you, for I have a high opinion of that little production myself" He was always perfectly honest in his expressions about his ovm writings, and it was delightful to hear him praise them when he could depend on his listeners. A friend congratulated him once on that touch in "Vanity Fair" in which Becky " admires " her husband wlien he is giving Steyne the punishment which ruins her for life.
